title: Not Invented Here Syndrome
author: harryvederci
content:
Not Invented Here (NIH) Syndrome is a common problem in software development. It occurs when teams or organizations dismiss the use of existing solutions, instead opting to “reinvent the wheel”. This often happens due to pride, fear, or other factors that prevent teams from using existing solutions. NIH Syndrome can lead to increased costs, delays, and decreased quality.

To avoid this syndrome, teams should focus on the end goal, not the means of achieving it. They should also be willing to explore existing solutions, even if they don’t have the same level of control over them. Additionally, teams should ensure that they have the necessary resources and expertise to develop the solution in-house. If not, they should consider using an existing solution.

Finally, teams should be aware of the potential risks associated with NIH Syndrome. These include increased costs, delays, and decreased quality. If these risks are deemed too great, teams should consider using existing solutions. By doing so, teams can avoid the pitfalls of NIH Syndrome and focus on the task at hand.

title: Rabarbar – Generate website screenshots in Docker (headless)
author: ChopSticksPlz
content: Rabarbar is a website screenshot tool that runs in Docker and allows users to capture screenshots of websites in a headless environment. It is designed to be lightweight and fast, and can be easily integrated into existing workflows. Rabarbar can generate screenshots in multiple formats, including PNG, JPEG, and GIF, and allows users to specify the size and quality of the screenshot. It also supports HTML rendering and can be used to capture screenshots of dynamic webpages. Rabarbar is open source and free to use, making it an ideal choice for developers and webmasters who need to quickly generate website screenshots.

title: An Optimised Flow for Futures: From Theory to Practice
author: mpweiher
content:
an-optimised-flow-for-futures-from-theory-to-practice

This article discusses the concept of futures and how to effectively use them in practice. Futures are a type of concurrent programming construct which allow for asynchronous execution of tasks. They are used to encapsulate a computation that may take some time to complete and can be used to improve the performance of applications. The article looks at how to create an optimized flow for futures, from theory to practice. It first outlines the theoretical basis for futures and then goes on to discuss how to use them in practice. This includes topics such as how to create futures, how to manage concurrency, and how to debug and test them. Finally, the article looks at how to use futures in a real-world application and provides some best practices for doing so. The article provides a comprehensive overview of how to use futures effectively and provides practical advice for implementing them in a production environment.

title: US to impose inflation fines on first set of drugs, lowering costs
author: ianai
content: The US government has announced it will be imposing inflation fines on the first set of drugs in order to lower their costs. The fines are part of a new rule that will take effect in 2024, and will apply to drugs that have seen an increase in cost that is higher than the inflation rate. The fines will be paid to the federal government, and the money will be used to reduce the cost of drugs for consumers. The rule will apply to drugs that are not covered by Medicare or Medicaid, and the fines will be based on the difference between the drug's current price and its price in 2018. The fines will only apply to drugs that have seen a price increase of 10% or more since 2018. The government hopes that the fines will encourage drug makers to keep their prices in check, and will ultimately lead to lower drug costs for consumers.

title: Google Releases Palm API
author: nwoli
content: Google has released a new Palm API and MakerSuite, a set of tools for developers to create applications for their devices. The API allows developers to access their device’s sensors, display, and other hardware. It also provides access to the Google Play Store and other services. Additionally, MakerSuite provides a suite of tools to help developers create, test, and publish their applications. The suite includes a code editor, a simulator, and a debugging tool. It also provides support for multiple languages, including Java, Python, and JavaScript. With the new API, developers can easily build applications for their devices, providing users with more features and a better experience. The new API and MakerSuite are available now and are free to use.

title: Test Flakiness Across Programming Languages
author: mpweiher
content: This article discusses the issue of test flakiness, which is when tests fail randomly without any changes in the code. The article looks at the issue across different programming languages. It finds that test flakiness is a problem in all programming languages, but is especially prevalent in dynamic languages such as JavaScript and Python. It also finds that test flakiness increases with the complexity of the code, and that it is more likely to occur in asynchronous code. The article suggests that developers should use a combination of techniques to reduce test flakiness, such as making tests more deterministic, using mocking frameworks, and using test runners that are optimized for the language being used.

title: It’s important that cyber security advice is tailored to the intended audience
author: mariuz
content: This article discusses the importance of tailoring cyber security advice to the intended audience. It states that cyber security advice should be tailored to the particular audience in order to be effective. This is because different audiences have different needs and levels of understanding when it comes to cyber security. For example, a business may need more detailed advice than a home user. It is also important to ensure that the advice is appropriate for the audience's level of knowledge and understanding, as well as their particular needs. The article concludes that cyber security advice should be tailored to the intended audience in order to be effective and ensure that the audience understands the advice and is able to follow it.

title: AI detector – find out if a text is generated from ChatGPT
author: susanvilleula1
content: AI Detector is an online tool that helps users to determine if a text has been generated by ChatGPT. It uses advanced AI algorithms to analyze the text and detect any signs of AI-generated content. The tool is useful for detecting plagiarism, fraud, and other forms of content manipulation. It can also be used to detect AI-generated content in social media posts, blog posts, and other types of content. The tool is easy to use and provides users with a detailed report of the text's authenticity. It also provides users with a summary of the AI-generated content and a list of potential sources. AI Detector is a powerful tool that can help users protect their content and ensure that their work is original.

title: How to use Prometheus for web application monitoring
author: jorzel
content: Prometheus is a powerful monitoring system that can be used to monitor web applications. This article explains how to use Prometheus for web application monitoring. First, it explains how to install and configure Prometheus and its exporters. Then, it explains how to create dashboards and alerts in Prometheus. Finally, it explains how to use Grafana to visualize Prometheus metrics. In conclusion, this article provides a comprehensive guide to setting up Prometheus for web application monitoring. With Prometheus, users can monitor their web applications and get alerted when something goes wrong.

title: How Much Does It Cost to Develop an On-Demand Taxi Service App Like Uber?
author: Kathyjohn
content: This article examines the cost of developing an on-demand taxi service app like Uber. The overall cost will vary depending on the features and complexity of the app. Generally, the cost of developing such an app can range from $20,000 to $50,000. This cost includes the cost of hiring a development team, designing the app, developing the app, and testing the app. Additionally, the cost of hosting the app and maintaining it for the long term should be taken into consideration. The cost of marketing the app should also be factored in, as it is essential for the success of the app. Finally, the cost of setting up payment systems, such as credit card processing, should also be taken into account. In conclusion, developing an on-demand taxi service app like Uber will require a significant investment, but the potential rewards can be significant.

title: From Zendesk to ChatGPT: Leveraging Embeddings
author: tiagopavan
content: This article explores how embeddings can be used to create a more powerful customer service chatbot. Embeddings are a way of representing words and phrases using numerical vectors, which allows for more accurate analysis of customer conversations. The article uses the example of Zendesk, a customer service platform, to illustrate how embeddings can be used to improve the customer experience. The article then introduces ChatGPT, a chatbot that uses embeddings to help customers find answers to their questions faster. ChatGPT is able to understand customer intent and provide them with the most relevant answers. The article concludes by discussing the potential of embeddings and how they can be used to create more powerful customer service chatbots. Embeddings are a powerful tool that can be used to improve customer service and provide customers with faster, more accurate answers.

title: The mice with two dads: scientists create eggs from male cells
author: geox
content: Scientists have successfully created mouse eggs from male cells in a breakthrough study. This is the first time that eggs have been created from male cells, and could have implications for the future of fertility treatments. The research was conducted by a team of scientists from the University of Bath and the Francis Crick Institute, who used stem cells derived from male mouse tails to create eggs. The eggs were then fertilized with sperm and implanted into female mice, who then gave birth to healthy offspring. This research could potentially lead to new treatments for infertility, as well as provide new insights into the development of egg cells. It could also help to further our understanding of fertility and the potential for creating eggs from male cells in other species.

title: Prefer Views:Meow
author: ibobev
content: This article is a tweet from Yoav Anaki, a software engineer, that talks about the advantages of preferring views over stored procedures. He explains that views are easier to maintain and debug, as they are written in the same language as the application code. Additionally, views can be used to abstract away complex queries, making them easier to use. Furthermore, views are more secure because they are not executed directly on the database, so they are not vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. Finally, views can be used to create a consistent data model, making it easier to query the data. In conclusion, Yoav Anaki believes that views are preferable to stored procedures.

title: For ChatGPT, “knowledge” can come at the expense of “intelligence”
author: hackathonguy
content: ChatGPT is a new technology that has been developed to help messaging services become more interoperable. It is based on a "knowledge graph" that is used to map out the interactions between users. The technology is designed to help messaging services to better understand the context of conversations and to provide more accurate responses. However, it has been noted that while the technology is able to provide more accurate responses, it can also lead to a decrease in the "intelligence" of the conversations. This is because the knowledge graph can only provide limited information and does not take into account the nuances of human conversation. As a result, conversations may become more robotic and less engaging. In order to address this issue, the developers of ChatGPT are looking to add more features to the technology that will help to increase the intelligence of conversations. This includes the use of natural language processing and machine learning to better understand the context of conversations and to provide more accurate and engaging responses.

title: The DMA Stakeholder Workshop: Interoperability between messaging services
author: jacooper
content: The DMA Stakeholder Workshop was held to discuss the challenges of interoperability between messaging services. The workshop was attended by representatives from a variety of messaging services and communication providers, including WhatsApp, Facebook, Google, Apple, and Skype. The discussion focused on the need for a common set of standards that would ensure seamless interoperability between the different messaging services. The workshop also discussed the potential benefits of such a system, such as improved user experience, better security, and increased efficiency. Additionally, the participants discussed the potential challenges of such a system, such as privacy and data protection issues, as well as the need for a unified system of authentication. The workshop concluded with a commitment from the participants to work together to develop a unified set of standards for interoperability. The DMA Stakeholder Workshop provided a platform for industry leaders to discuss the challenges and benefits of interoperability between messaging services, and the potential for a unified system of standards.

title: Landmark quantum breakthrough paves way for world-first experimental wormhole
author: wjSgoWPm5bWAhXB
content: This article discusses a landmark breakthrough in quantum physics which could open the door to the potential of creating a world-first experimental wormhole. The breakthrough was achieved by a team of scientists at the University of Queensland who developed a new technique called 'quantum teleportation'. This technique allows for the transfer of quantum information from one particle to another at the speed of light, enabling the potential for a wormhole to be created. The scientists believe that this breakthrough could have far-reaching implications for the future of quantum computing, communication, and even space travel. The team is now working on further experiments to test their theory and potentially create a working wormhole. This breakthrough could revolutionize the way we think about quantum physics and could lead to a number of exciting new applications.

title: Apple Supplier Foxconn Plans to Rely Less on China for Revenue
author: mfiguiere
content: Foxconn, a major supplier for Apple, is planning to reduce its reliance on China for revenue. Foxconn is looking to diversify its production to other countries such as India, Vietnam, and Mexico. The company is looking to invest $1 billion in India in order to set up manufacturing facilities and expand its production there. Foxconn is also planning to invest in research and development in India in order to tap into the country's pool of tech talent. Additionally, Foxconn is looking to expand its presence in Vietnam and Mexico. The company is planning to invest $270 million in Vietnam and $200 million in Mexico. The move is part of Foxconn's strategy to reduce its dependence on China and to diversify its production. The company is hoping that this move will help it to remain competitive in the global market.

title: Show HN: A Simple AlphaZero Implementation
author: scascin0
content: This article discusses a simple AlphaZero implementation and how it can be used as a "Rorschach test" for artificial intelligence. AlphaZero is a reinforcement learning algorithm that uses a deep neural network to learn from self-play. Finally, the article concludes with a discussion of the potential applications of AlphaZero, such as creating AI agents for more complex tasks.

author: ibobev
content:
/blob/master/stories/rorschach-test-on-fire.md

The system was also able to detect the emotions of the creator of the inkblot. title: The Evolution of Cognition
author: bbenzon
content:
-service/

The Evolution of Cognition is an article that explores the evolution of cognitive abilities in humans and other animals. It discusses the concept of “cognitive niche construction”, which is the idea that cognitive abilities can be developed and improved through the use of tools and technology. The article also looks at the potential for cognitive enhancement through the use of artificial intelligence (AI) and virtual reality (VR). The article points out that while AI and VR can provide powerful tools to enhance cognition, they can also be used to manipulate and control humans in ways that are unethical. The article suggests that it is important to consider the ethical implications of using AI and VR to enhance cognition and to ensure that such technologies are used responsibly. Finally, the article looks at how Be My Eyes, a virtual volunteer service, is using AI and VR to help people with vision impairments. Be My Eyes provides a platform for people with vision impairments to connect with volunteers who can help them with tasks such as reading labels or navigating their environment. The article concludes that Be My Eyes is an example of how AI and VR can be used in a positive and ethical way to enhance cognition.

The tool would be able to provide assistance with everyday tasks, such as reading text, navigating unfamiliar environments, and identifying objects. It would also be able to use its deep learning capabilities to recognize objects in the environment and provide relevant information. The authors conclude that with the right design, GPT-4 could be used to create a powerful virtual volunteer tool that could help blind and low vision people in their everyday lives.

title: Handbook for CTFers: Zero to One
author: teleforce
content:
-ctf

The Handbook for CTFers: Zero to One is a guide created by Taichi-dev to help CTFers of all levels increase their skills and knowledge. It provides an introduction to the basics of CTFs, including the different types of CTFs, the different tools used, and the different skills and techniques needed to be successful. It also covers topics such as cryptography, reverse engineering, web exploitation, and binary exploitation. Additionally, it provides an overview of the different types of challenges that can be found in CTFs, such as Jeopardy, Attack-Defend, and Reversing. Finally, the guide contains tips and tricks on how to approach CTFs, as well as a list of resources that can be used to further develop skills and knowledge. The guide is intended to be a comprehensive resource for CTFers of all levels, from those who are completely new to the world of CTFs to those who are already experienced.

title: Credit Suisse Default Swaps Are 18 Times UBS, 9 Times Deutsche Bank
author: mfiguiere
content: Credit Suisse’s one-year default swaps have reached a record high of nearly 1,000 basis points, making it 18 times more expensive than UBS and nine times more expensive than Deutsche Bank. This is due to the bank's exposure to Archegos Capital Management, a U.S. family office, which defaulted on margin calls last week. Credit Suisse has been hit especially hard by the default, with the bank's stock price falling by as much as 16% on Monday. Credit Suisse is estimated to have lost around $4.7 billion due to its involvement with Archegos Capital. Other banks such as UBS and Nomura have also been affected, but Credit Suisse has taken the biggest hit. The Swiss bank has said it is taking steps to manage its risks and strengthen its capital position.

title: Why Are All Action Heroes Named Jack, James, or John?
author: Jun8
content: The article discusses the prevalence of action heroes with names beginning with "J" (Jack, James, or John). It notes that this is a common trend in both American and British action films, and that it is a reflection of how these films often depict traditional masculinity. The article then goes on to explore the history of action heroes with "J" names, beginning with John Wayne in the 1940s, who set the tone for the following decades. It also examines the more recent incarnations of these characters, such as John Wick and James Bond, noting that these characters are often seen as the epitome of traditional masculinity. The article concludes by noting that this trend reflects a larger cultural shift towards traditional masculinity, and that it is likely to continue for some time.

title: Credit Suisse shares slide 24% after Saudi backer rules out further assistance
author: mfiguiere
content:
Credit Suisse shares dropped 24% on Monday after Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) ruled out further assistance to the Swiss bank. The bank has been struggling with a $4.4 billion loss due to a trading scandal in its investment banking division, and the PIF had previously provided a $10 billion bailout package.

The PIF had been in talks with Credit Suisse to provide additional financial support, but announced they would no longer be doing so. The PIF will still retain its position as one of the bank’s top investors, with a stake of around 5%.

Credit Suisse CEO Thomas Gottstein said the bank is “disappointed” with the PIF’s decision and is now exploring “alternative solutions” to shore up its capital. He added that the bank remains “well capitalized” and has a “strong balance sheet”.

Credit Suisse shares fell 24% on Monday after the Saudi Arabian Public Investment Fund (PIF) ruled out further financial assistance to the Swiss bank. The PIF had previously provided a $10 billion bailout package to help the bank recover from a $4.4 billion loss due to a trading scandal. Credit Suisse CEO Thomas Gottstein said the bank is “disappointed” with the PIF’s decision and is now exploring “alternative solutions” to shore up its capital. The PIF will still retain its position as one of the bank’s top investors, with a stake of around 5%.

title: Docker is deleting Open Source organisations - what you need to know
author: alexellisuk
content:
Docker is a popular container platform used by many companies and developers to deploy and manage applications. Recently, Docker has been deleting some of its open source images from its registry. This has caused concern among the open source community, as it could potentially harm open source projects and limit the ability of developers to use Docker for their projects.

The main issue is that Docker has been removing images that don't meet its new policies, without any warning or explanation. This has caused confusion and frustration among developers who rely on these images to build and deploy their applications.

Docker has stated that it is committed to open source, but it is important for developers to be aware of the changes that are happening. They should review the policies and take steps to ensure that their images comply with them. Additionally, they should look into other container platforms, such as Kubernetes, that may offer more flexibility and better support for open source projects.

Finally, Ashley talks about how the pathfinding system needs to be tested and balanced to make sure it works correctly and doesn't cause too much strain on the game's performance.

title: Secret Chip Deals Help US Tech Flow to Russia Despite Sanctions
author: helsinkiandrew
content: A recent Bloomberg investigation has revealed that US technology is being illegally supplied to Russia despite sanctions being in place. The investigation uncovered a network of chip brokers and distributors who are supplying Russian companies with US-made computer chips that are banned from export to Russia. The chips are used to power a wide range of products, from drones and military communications systems to medical equipment. The brokers and distributors are using a variety of methods to evade US export controls, including false invoices, mislabeled packages, and fake end-user certificates. The US government has been aware of the issue since at least 2012, but has yet to take any meaningful action to stop the flow of US technology to Russia. This is likely due to the difficulty of tracking down the brokers and distributors, as well as the fact that Russia is a major customer for US chip makers.

title: Why Bluetooth audio quality suffers in video calls
author: makaimc
content: Bluetooth audio quality can suffer when used in video calls due to the way Bluetooth works. Bluetooth is a wireless protocol that uses a technique called Frequency Hopping Spread Spectrum (FHSS) to transmit audio. FHSS sends audio over a wide range of frequencies, which can cause interference with other wireless signals such as Wi-Fi or cellular data. This interference can result in audio distortion, echoing, and other sound degradation. Additionally, Bluetooth audio is compressed, which can further reduce sound quality. To improve the audio quality of Bluetooth-enabled video calls, users can use a wired headset, switch to a different wireless protocol such as Wi-Fi, or use a dedicated audio system that is designed to handle multiple audio streams. By taking these steps, users can ensure that their audio quality is as good as possible during video calls.

title: Lambda Invoke: The Minimal Loveable API
author: senzilla
content: Lambda Invoke is a minimal, loveable API for serverless computing. It allows developers to quickly and easily deploy applications to the cloud. It uses a simple, intuitive syntax to make deployment fast and easy. Lambda Invoke is based on the popular open source project, Serverless, and is designed to make deploying applications to the cloud even easier. It supports a wide range of programming languages, including Node.js, Python, Java, and Go, and allows developers to quickly deploy their applications without having to manage infrastructure. Lambda Invoke also provides a range of features to help developers manage their applications, including monitoring, logging, and debugging. It also provides a range of helpful tools for debugging and troubleshooting. Lambda Invoke is an excellent choice for developers who want to quickly and easily deploy their applications to the cloud. It is easy to use, provides a range of features to help manage applications, and supports a wide range of programming languages.

title: 2024 GMC Hummer EV SUV Uses Enormous Battery to Charge Other Electric Cars
author: clouddrover
content: The GMC Hummer EV SUV will be released in 2024 and is set to be a game-changer in the electric vehicle industry. It will feature an enormous battery pack that will be able to charge other electric cars. This battery will be the largest ever fitted to an electric vehicle and will have a capacity of around 200 kWh. This will enable the vehicle to charge other electric cars up to 20 times faster than current models. The Hummer EV SUV will also be able to provide up to 400 miles of range on a single charge, making it one of the most efficient electric vehicles on the market. In addition, the SUV will have a range of features such as adaptive air suspension, four-wheel steering, and a torque vectoring system. The Hummer EV SUV is set to revolutionize the electric vehicle industry and will be a great choice for those looking for a powerful and efficient electric vehicle.

title: Silicon Valley Bank unmasks the hypocrisy of libertarian tech bros
author: marban
content: Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) is a major financial institution that has been accused of hypocrisy for its role in the collapse of the libertarian tech bros. SVB has been accused of lending money to tech companies with little oversight, leading to the downfall of many of these companies. The article argues that the libertarian tech bros of Silicon Valley have embraced a free-market ideology, but have ultimately failed to live up to their own ideals. SVB has been accused of taking advantage of the free-market system to make money, while at the same time failing to regulate the companies it lends to. It is argued that this has resulted in a lack of accountability and transparency, leading to the downfall of many tech companies. The article calls on Silicon Valley to take responsibility for its actions and to hold itself to the same standards it has set for its own clients. In conclusion, the article argues that the collapse of SVB is a reminder of the need for regulation and oversight in the tech industry, and that Silicon Valley needs to be held accountable for its actions.

title: The benefits of a customized packing and moving plan
author: alrazayam
content: Customized packing and moving plans are beneficial for those looking to move. They provide an organized and efficient approach to the process. These plans can be tailored to the specific needs of the individual, taking into account the size of the move, the timeline, and the budget. Customized plans can also be used to reduce the stress of the move by providing detailed instructions for the packing and unpacking process. Furthermore, the plans can be used to identify potential problems and resolve them before they become an issue. Additionally, customized plans can help to ensure that the move is completed safely and securely, as they provide detailed instructions on how to properly pack and move fragile items. Lastly, customized plans can help to save time and money by helping to identify potential savings opportunities. All in all, customized packing and moving plans are a great way to make the moving process easier and more efficient.

content: This article discusses the use of DNS64 and NAT64 on OpenBSD. DNS64 is a DNS protocol that allows for IPv6-only clients to access IPv4-only content. NAT64 is a network protocol that allows IPv6-only clients to access IPv4-only resources. The article explains how to configure OpenBSD to use DNS64 and NAT64, as well as how to use the Unbound DNS server to set up a DNS64/NAT64 gateway. It also provides a sample configuration file and a list of resources to help with the setup. The article concludes by noting that DNS64/NAT64 can be a useful tool for organizations that need to provide access to IPv4-only resources from IPv6-only clients.

title: Request for protocol: Double-blind messaging for knowledge fragmentation
author: szpasztor
content: This article discusses the need for a protocol that would enable double-blind messaging for knowledge fragmentation. Knowledge fragmentation occurs when knowledge and information is spread across multiple sources, making it difficult to access and use. The proposed protocol would allow for secure communication between parties and would enable the secure sharing of data. The protocol would also provide a way for organizations to collaborate and share knowledge in a secure and private manner. Additionally, it would help to reduce the risk of data breaches and would provide a way to securely store and access data. The protocol would also help to reduce the cost of managing data and would help to ensure data integrity. The article concludes by noting that the proposed protocol would be beneficial to organizations and individuals alike, and that it should be implemented as soon as possible.

title: The state of Computer Vision and AI: we are really, really far away (2012)
author: lysozyme
content: In this video, computer scientist Andrew Ng discusses the current state of computer vision and artificial intelligence (AI). He explains that while computer vision and AI have made great strides in recent years, they are still far from achieving the level of sophistication of the human brain. Ng explains that current AI systems lack the ability to understand the context of an image or situation and are unable to make decisions in a meaningful way. He also mentions that AI systems are not able to recognize objects or patterns in the same way that humans can. Ng notes that while AI technology has improved, it is still a long way from being able to match the capabilities of the human brain. He believes that in order to achieve true AI, we need to focus on understanding the underlying principles of intelligence and building systems that can learn and adapt to new situations. Ng ends the video by stressing the importance of continued research and development in the field of AI in order for us to make progress in this area.

title: Do Covid-19 vaccine mandates still make sense?
author: pseudolus
content: This article examines the potential of vaccine mandates in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. Vaccine mandates are laws that require people to be vaccinated in order to access certain services or activities. The article argues that vaccine mandates may be a useful tool to encourage people to get vaccinated, but they are not a silver bullet and should be used with caution. The article suggests that mandates should only be used when there is a clear public health benefit, and they should be tailored to the needs of the population. The article also notes that there are ethical concerns with mandates, such as the potential for coercion and the unequal access to vaccines. The article concludes that vaccine mandates are a potentially useful tool, but they should be used judiciously and with consideration for the ethical implications.

title: What's the difference between ports and pkgs – A FreeBSD beginners guide
author: rodrigo975
content:
whats-the-difference-between-ports-and-pkgs-a-freebsd-beginners-guide

Ports and packages are two different methods of installing applications on FreeBSD operating systems. Ports are a collection of Makefiles, patches and description files that are used to compile and install an application from source code. Packages, on the other hand, are pre-compiled binary files that contain all the necessary files for an application to run. Packages are much easier to install than ports, as they require less user interaction and are faster to install. However, packages are only available for the version of FreeBSD that they were compiled for, and may not be available for other versions. Ports, on the other hand, can be compiled for any version of FreeBSD, and can be customized to fit the user’s needs. In addition, ports are often more up-to-date than packages, as they are updated more frequently. Both ports and packages have their advantages and disadvantages, and it is up to the user to decide which method is best for their needs.

title: Researcher solves nearly 60-year-old game theory dilemma
author: pseudolus
content:
A researcher has solved a nearly 60-year-old game theory dilemma known as the "Prisoner's Dilemma". The dilemma was first proposed in 1950 by mathematician Albert Tucker and has been used to study decision-making in a wide range of fields, including economics and political science. The dilemma presents two prisoners with a choice: cooperate with one another and both receive a reduced sentence, or both defect and receive a more severe punishment.

The researcher, Dr. Ariel Procaccia from Carnegie Mellon University, developed a new algorithm which solves the dilemma by allowing each prisoner to choose a strategy which maximizes their own benefit, while still ensuring cooperation from the other prisoner. The algorithm can be used in a wide range of applications, from economics to politics, and can be used to help make better decisions in situations where cooperation is essential.

title: At Long Last, a Donkey Family Tree
author: Amorymeltzer
content:
Tutor_Datasets/blob/master/DonkeyFamilyTree.txt

For the first time, a comprehensive family tree of the donkey has been constructed. Researchers from the University of Veterinary Medicine Vienna, the University of Veterinary Medicine Hannover, and the Leibniz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research worked together to create the tree. By analyzing the DNA of 1,500 donkeys from around the world, the researchers were able to trace the evolutionary history of the species.

The results show that donkeys originated from wild asses in the Middle East and Africa, and were domesticated around 5,000 years ago. The family tree also reveals that the donkey is closely related to the horse, and that certain breeds are more closely related to each other than others. This research provides a valuable resource for understanding the history of the donkey and its relationship to other equids.

title: Open Piano: an open source piano engine based on physical modeling
author: hggh
content: Open Piano is an open source piano engine based on physical modeling. It is designed to provide realistic piano sounds and a variety of playing styles. The engine uses advanced physical modeling techniques to accurately simulate the behavior of a real piano. It is capable of producing a wide range of sounds, from mellow and gentle to bright and powerful. The engine also allows for a variety of playing styles, from light and delicate to aggressive and powerful. Open Piano is designed to be used in any environment, from home studios to professional recording studios. It is easy to use and requires no special hardware or software. The engine is also highly customizable, allowing users to adjust the sound, the playing style, and the overall feel of the instrument. Open Piano is an ideal solution for those looking for a realistic, customizable, and affordable piano engine.

title: Collato – the AI search engine for product teams
author: cwindorf
content: Collato is an AI search engine designed to help product teams find the best solutions for their products. It uses a combination of natural language processing and machine learning to help teams quickly identify the best options for their products. Collato uses a system of “units of simile” to compare different products and find the best fit. The system applies a set of criteria to each product and then compares the results to find the best fit. Collato also incorporates a “multi-dimensional scoring system” which takes into account a variety of factors such as cost, features, and user experience. By using this system, product teams can quickly identify the best solution for their product. Collato is an innovative and powerful tool that can help product teams save time and money while finding the best solution for their product.

title: The Si Units of Simile
author: mkarliner
content:
the-si-units-of-simile/

The SI Units of Simile is an article that looks at the use of similes in the English language. A simile is a figure of speech that compares two different things, usually using the words "like" or "as." The article explains that similes are used to help readers better understand a concept by providing a more vivid description. It also explains that there are two types of similes: literal and figurative. Literal similes compare two different things directly, while figurative similes use more creative language to make a comparison. The article also looks at the importance of using the right type of simile for the context, as using the wrong type can lead to confusion or misunderstanding. Finally, the article provides a number of examples of similes to help readers better understand the concept. By looking at the use of similes in the English language, this article provides a useful guide for readers who want to use similes in their own writing.

title: Xunzi – The Heart-Mind
author: abudabi123
content: Xunzi was a Chinese philosopher who lived during the Warring States period. He is best known for his work, "The Heart-Mind," which is a collection of essays written between 300 and 250 BC. In this work, Xunzi argued that the heart-mind is the source of all knowledge and morality. He believed that the heart-mind is the highest form of moral authority, and that it should be the basis of any moral decision. He argued that the heart-mind is an innate part of human nature, and that it can be developed through education and practice. Xunzi argued that the heart-mind is the only valid source of knowledge, and that it should be used to guide one's actions. He believed that the heart-mind is the only way to achieve true wisdom and morality, and that it should be used to guide one's life. Xunzi's work has been influential to Chinese philosophy, and his ideas have been adopted by many schools of thought throughout the centuries. His work is still studied today, and his ideas are still relevant to modern life.
